REVIEW_BODY:
Great satay, and priced reasonably. You will be pushed by a number of stall holders to by from them but they‚Äôre all selling the same thing, some are more polite than others so I tended towards them.

The skewers are small, our family of four, including a teenage boy ate 100, this consisted of 10 prawn (devine!!!), 45 chicken and 45 beef. We also purchased some Bok Choy from another vendor, this was delicious.

We were in Singapore nearly 30yrs ago and went to the Satay Solo Club, this is no longer there and it appears this (Satay Club) has replaced it.

Enjoy!

Arrived at satay street and was greeted immediately. Satay 7&8 showed me the menu, took my order, and got a seat for us all quickly and efficiently.
We ordered the $26 set (10 chicken, 10 beef, 5 prawns)

Food arrived at our table within about 10-12 mins, and tasted glorious!

The whole experience was fantastic, and I‚Äôd recommend a visit to Satay Street to anybody visiting Singapore.

We will be back before our trip is over!
Brilliant night out tried all the local skewers, definitely a recommendation. Best time to visit is in the evening when the roads are closed off.

We were worried we couldn‚Äôt get our Satays on our last day in Singapore because it was raining. All good you can sit inside the hawker market and get them inside. Enjoyed our meal of chicken and beef Satays and also some delicious naan bread . Delicious !

This place is fantastic great service they will find you a table and take your order. Someone else will come for your drink order. This is a must go to place when in Singapore I will definitely be back next trip.

REVIEW_TITLE: OK but not what it used to be.
REVIEW_BODY:
Visited one evening with 2 kids after having visited Satay Street over 15 years previously. Initially we didn‚Äôt get off to a good start as the taxi driver somehow didn‚Äôt know where Satay Street actually was (he dropped us off in Chinatown rather than on Boon Tat Street.) Eventually we found the right location (Watch out - not all sat navs have Satay street listed.) We then made the mistake of being led to a table and having a menu thrust upon us, when really we should have seated ourselves and chosen the stall we preferred.

We ordered a mixed satay (chicken, beef and prawn) and mixed steamed veg. The food was good, although seemed to be more prawn than anything else, pricing however was akin to restaurant pricing, which was dissapointing.

One bit of advice is to take your own napkins or wet wipes, or buy them from the 7-Eleven next to the seating area. Street sellers go up and down the tables selling wet wipes and are very good at appearing over your shoulder to push very overpriced wet wipe packs, just at the point when you are covered in Satay!

Unfortunately (as is often the case with kids and lots of soft drinks,) we had to find a toilet part way through the meal. We were pointed towards the market toilets which were an experience in themselves - not one for people with a sensitive sense of smell and they don‚Äôt help your appetite!

There is a good feel to the place with the sound and smells, surrounded by the skyscrapers of the CBD, but it‚Äôs not as good as it used to be.

REVIEW_TITLE: Worth a visit, Bring your own napkins!!!!
REVIEW_BODY:
The Best stands according to many locals are #7 & 8. Because of the sauce. and I like their shrimp.
$0.70 per stick, the rice cakes are$1 (long boiled rice in a small bag, served cold.) Beer is $5.50 flag down a Tiger lady in Red.
Have been many times to the Satay street. Opens at 7pm on Friday and all day on Sat/Sun. Go in the later evening. You can get any food from inside and eat outside as well. pay just cash.

Tip: Bring your own napkins!!!!
Satays were ok. Tasted better. Food vendors were pushy to buy their food so didn't fully experience overall atmosphere of place.

We ate here twice during our stay in Singapore, the second time at the request of our 14 & 10 year olds. We ordered from Stall 7 & 8 both times & were extremely satisfied with our chicken, beef & prawn skewers. The Satay sauce was delicious& the Naan bread fresh & tasty. We would thoroughly recommend Stall 7 & 8.

Really enjoyed dinner. ‚ÄòWaiters‚Äô from surrounding stalls seat you - they‚Äôll sell you the satay sticks from one stall; then they‚Äôll try and sell you something else from their own stall... like a vege side dish or some noodles. All the food we had was delicious and cheap. We went back the next night and ordered directly at the stalls that we wanted - this was probably a better way of doing things.

REVIEW_TITLE: Over rated just plain satay which took ages to arrive
REVIEW_BODY:
We went to stall 7 and 8 as my wife had researched this and it‚Äôs meant to be the best. We ordered a set and after 40 minutes it had still not arrived. We then chased it and the lab arrive and then we had to wait and then chase for the chicken and prawns. When they all finally arrived they were disappointing. They are just plain satay not particularly juicy and the sauce was not special either.

I have had much better satay elsewhere and won‚Äôt be returning.

The satay street is well worth the visit and the food is excellent. We ate at ‚Äò7 and 8‚Äô and although not cheap the sticks were certainly delicious.

What to expect:
- a large hawker centre and the satay street to the side
- lots of pushy staff trying to get u to eat their food
- $26 for 26 sticks on a set menu from where we ate
- beer girls who come to ur table, tip walk 20m to the 7/11 on satay street (directly in front of 7 and 8) and buy it for half price and twice the freshness.
- u pay when u get the food
- nearest metro is Raffles
- if u want anything else other than satay best walk into the centre for the endless selections.
Just had a great evening on Satay St. Lovley relaxed atmosphere. Recommend you go for a walk and view the stalls before you order. The banana martabark was also excellent.

Satay Street is basically a group of satay stalls located adjacent to the covered food court at Lu Pasat. It is pretty crowded in the evenings and seems to be pretty popular with the locals. The menu is limited to different kind of satays and one might find the prices a bit higher when compared to satays in other food courts.

We arrived before 7 and wandered around the food court wandering how the place had been recommended for Satays. As we were leaving, choosing not to eat, we were approached by someone offering satays. This was just before 7, it was then we found out that's when the road is closed and the 'satay street' comes to life. Great food. We did the obligatory satays and also roti bread. Ladies wander the tables bringing bear to you. Best way to order that is by the jug!! Great food and atmosphere!

The experience on 'Satay Street' is noisy, chaotic with wonderful aromas from the satay BBQ's. The worst part is having all the vendors pushing you to eat at their stall when you're wandering for a look - small hassle, easily ignored!

If you want a good satay this is the place to go, stall 8 proclaim themselves as the best and I couldn't really fault them, so much so that my daughter asked to go back for dinner another night before we left Singapore.

The satays are cooked fresh in front of you, are tasty with a moorish satay dipping sauce. It's not super cheap, but is a budget friendly option for dinner.

Was recommended to come here by our taxi driver for the best value satays in Singapore. We were not let down. Satays were amazing, well priced and service was very prompt. We sat outside amongst the sizzling satay vendors. Was very busy and all the satay vendors were very eager to have you visit their satay stall. Worth a visit as its very lively and has a good atmosphere. We also visited Newton night markets, not as well priced but still very good and close to Orchard rd.

REVIEW_TITLE: great way to while away the evening
REVIEW_BODY:
Visited twice during our week long stay. Had such a great night the first time. look out when ordering prawn skewers, most are not peeled and come with the shell still on.
Might be a delicacy in some parts, but we found it to be just a messy experience.
We went to stall 3-4 both nights, see Bobo. He was great at looking after his guests, making sure we had plenty of food and drinks as he cruised the tables.. A place that we will visit again, next time we are in Singapore.

We were visiting Singapore and were taken here by a friend who resides in Singapore. We had a great evening and found the food to be delicious and well cooked and presented and the prices very reasonable. The mutton, chicken and beef stays were great, so we're the prawn ones and the crab in black bean sauce. If you don't want to eat outside you can come inside under cover - we had a table under a fan, which was great.
Really liked the Best satay of the town, bought at stall 7/8. Funny though, the sauce wasn't half as hot and spicy as I'd imagined it would be.

Go to 7&8. Great food, so many options. Great service. Fun atmosphere. Prices not too bad, and plenty to drink, as long as you‚Äôre happy with beer. Some very local food options if you‚Äôre brave enough.
We go here often. It's a great street atmosphere with a great night out vibe. Food is always good. Highly recommend a visit here if you live or stop in Singapore.

This is a great outdoors eating venue just like some of the old pasar Malays of night markets from the 1970s. The range of food is excellent and the prices are competitive too. We had the chicken and beef satay and the popiah which were tasty and nutritious. Well worth a visit. And it‚Äôs a short walk to the bay front park. Beautiful at night.

We visited Satay Street a couple of times during our stay in Singapore and the satay everytime was fantastic. I didn't find the staff overly pushy to visit each stall, a simple no thank you usually enough for them to leave you alone. I also wouldn't be overly concerned with which stall you go with. Prices and quality are mostly consistent with each other, really comes down to your preference on the satay sauce more than anything. So don't be afraid to try the other stalls. Recommend buying drinks from the 7 Eleven close by, napkins too if you'd like, although they aren't that much cheaper than the sellers going around.

Overall it's good satay sitting among sky scrapers, even better when it rains and everyone scrambles for cover.

It really is worth it to come to Satay Street for the whole experience of all the smells and sights of a road being taken over with tables and chairs with high rise offices all around town in the name of Satay. We went to stalls 7 & 8 as recommended on trip advisor and we weren‚Äôt disappointed at all! The beef satay was especially nice and tender!

If you are in Singapore and want to sample some street food you need to go to Satay Street. Stalls 7 & 8, the satay is fantastic, the service was quick and the price is great too. We were served at our table someone brought drink around too. Delicious mix of satay sticks with chunks of onion and cucumber and the salty sauce was think and delicious too. Highly recommend this place we saw it advertised on YouTube and was so worth going. When we return to Singapore it will be top of our list.
wonderful local experience. this is what you want to experience in Singapore. Don't worry about food hygiene, it is a dictatorship which cares about its visitors tummies.

Great place, we went 3 times. They close off a street by the Lau Pa Sat Hawker Centre at 7pm. Even a few minuets earlier sometimes. If you get there early enough you can get a table up the steps by the Tiger Beer Stall. Various staff from stalls/restaurants will try to find you seats, but you can sit your self. We use the TA recommended stall 7&8, but they all look good. We would enjoy a beer or two before ordering, just taking in the atmosphere. Several restaurants/stalls will bring menus when you sit down. Don't worry though, you can order from anyone, or find food inside and bring it back to your table. They'll hassle you for a bit if you don't order, but eventually they'll leave you alone. Tables are for any stall/restaurant. We usually did a half order from Stall 7&8, combining that with stir fried rice from a stall inside. Our last night we just ordering a couple prawns and chicken satays with a nice shrimp noodle dish. (from inside) Tiger beer is fairly cheap here, and if you can get a smile from the older lady serving you‚Äôre doing well. Tiger beer waitress‚Äôs will ask if you want more as they pass by, so you can just enjoy your food. Inside the Hawker Centre you'll find lots of food options available, so find a table and enjoy.

Felt a bit scammed here...the mistake I think was allowing one of the guys to find us a seat and then the menus came to us. Prawns and chicken satays good...but the Thai-style fish cakes were really awful...rubbery and no taste. Some of the offerings were far from cheap too....restaurant prices! However....a good experience, just be careful what you order!

We couldn‚Äôt leave Singapore without visiting the Satay St. There are many stalls to choose food from, people are very nice and will offer you a table and a menu. Other stall holders will approach you to offer complementary foods such as vegetables, flat bread and side dishes. We decided to eat at the stall 8. Prices start from $26 for a set menu, we paid $41 for option B including 15 chicken + 15 beef + 10 prawn skewers. This will feed up to 2 people and comes with 2 cups of satay sauce and few veggies. Great night out, and best with a cold beer on a hot night. Cheers guys!
Satay was very good, grilled stingray also...except too pricey. Hawkers are a little pushy, but just pass by.

Boon Tat Street shuts in the evening to become Satay Street that is extremely popular with locals and tourists. The sensational aromas of chicken, beef and prawns cooking over smoky grill hot plates is very salivating. Once you find a table it's a matter of selecting a stall to buy your satay from. We ate at stalls Best Satay 7 and 8. The prawns, chicken and beef were all delicious as was the tasty satay sauce. You are no sooner seated than being approached to order a beer or soft drink. It's very popular and worthwhile destination. Go check it out when in Singapore.
Super tasty Satay in stalls 7 & 8. Had the prawn, chicken and mutton satays and all were really good Especially the Prawns! Busy area with a great crowd and really fast, friendly service.

We dined in satay street twice, and both times the quality of food was excellent.
I suggest to be there 6.50pm as the seating area (literally on the street) opens at 7pm. Its funny to see how fast they lay down tables and chairs from 7pm sharp (Last few cars haven't left the street yet and half of the street was already covered by table)
Best kiosks are 7&8. 30 sticks mixed of chicken, beef and prawn with an unlimited satay sauce for 41 Singapore dollars. Best drink to have is sugar cane, or local beer, but you can easily bring your beverage if you wish. Make sure you have napkins and serviettes to clean your hands after have dined as they not providing any, or there is a public hand wash sink.
We will definitely go back to dine at satay street
Some of the best satay I‚Äôve ever had - super relaxed and simple but the food is really a treat! Would recommend everyone visiting Singapore to go here.

I have eaten there more than a dozen times and love it. The food, the people and the atmosphere is fantastic. I mainly eat satays from stall #9, also, when you are there buy some wet wipes from the old guy, only s$2.00, he has been selling there for over 25 years. Do yourselves a favor and try it. Alex

REVIEW_TITLE: Worth visiting if you're in the area around 19:00
REVIEW_BODY:
Satay street pops up at 19:00 every evening beside the Lau Pa Sat hawker centre. The vibe and atmosphere is excellent with the stalls lined up along one side of the street and tables and benches placed on the road itself (which is closed to motor vehicles in order to accommodate Satay Street).

There are various (pushy) representatives of the stalls standing around who swoop in to try to convince you to buy from their stall. They take orders once you're seated and the satay usually arrives shortly thereafter. If you want beer, there are 'beer ladies' who patrol the area and can deliver you beer from the hawker centre.

The food isn't the cheapest or the best (though it isn't expensive nor is it sub par), but it's worth visiting for the overall experience!
Really e joyed the mixed satay.... all the stalls are pretty much the same for quality and price. Make sure you bring something with you to clean your hands after the food as it's a messy eat...
The road shuts to traffic at 7 pm and the tables and chairs come out. That in itself is quite a sight to see. Then the satay comes out to shine. A great variety on offer and all tastes catered for

If you like satay you will love this and it's cheap. There couldn't be a more descriptive name for an area than Satay street. There is rice, rice cakes,spring rolls and vegetables but the rest is Satay.
Every meat or fish you could think of. Take a dish with different meats and guess what it could be, great fun. Satay are skewer with meat and sauces barbequed . Lovely tasting and really enjoyed by all. We spent time talking with families and couples. You can tell it's good as the locals are there eating not just tourists. The locals we talked too recommended certain stalls. Good idea to talk as some are very hot and spicy.

A nice experience very busy expect to be hassled by owners all stores are same price 70 cents each for beef chicken although you need alot as they are vety small very close to mrt we ate at stall no 3 very friendly man very tasty food

REVIEW_TITLE: Stumbled on this gem Satay Power 7
REVIEW_BODY: Went to Lau Pa Sat and were lured outside by the smell of the bbq‚Äôs. And it was worth it. Satay Power 7 was where we landed and it was nice - we had a combo of chicken, beef and prawn. It was all good. You can get a bit hassled by other hawkers from inside stall - but they eventually go away. Tiger beer lady was a hoot. Beer and satay on the street on fold out tables and plastic chairs - what‚Äôs not to love in local Singapore.

Yes, not the cheapest Satay you will find but what a great place to spend an hour or so on an evening. Satay we had from stalls 7&8 was excellent, full of wonder flavour. Great street atmosphere, a real experience not to missed when visiting Singapore.

I had to look twice last night to confirm I was actually in Singapore and not Kuta. The street vendors in Satay street were nothing but rude in attempting to coerce us into their stalls and at times this rudeness verged on intimidation. I‚Äôm sure the satay was good but the experience was utterly disappointing. If you want a relaxed meal give Satay Street a miss.

Whats not to like with the smell and smoke of the satays cooking plus the bustle of the crowds. Right next to Lau Pa Sat the street is transformed at night into an outdoor dining area. There are various sellers and we have tried most and all are good. Skip the set and just order the quantities of each that you want at the per stick price. The Tiger bear ladies comb the tables and return quickly with your order. You can order and eat withing the hawker center but the outdoor experience is enjoyable.
Open in the night, the street close for satay seller. Many kinds of satay, shrimp, chicken, pork and beef.

My girlfriend and I visited here on a Friday evening around 9pm. It was very busy and bustling with a self generated atmosphere, no need for music or neon here.
We sought out stalls 7 & 8 which came highly recommended. They had no space for us outside their stall but led us up a small staircase to a table in front of the beer stall (happy days!). We placed our food order and then sat with our jug of beer soaking up the atmosphere. I don't know if it was a case of out of sight out of mind but our food did not turn up. Initially we did not query it because we were unsure on waiting times but finally it became obvious there was a problem. I went back to the stall and they had clearly forgotten about us, we then had to wait a while longer for our food.
The food itself was tasty. (Top tip, don't dismiss the lady who approaches your table selling wet wipes. No napkins and eating with your fingers - why didn't I just pay the lady that dollar!!)
All in all well worth a visit but try to keep in the line of sight of your chosen stall holder.

Satay Street in Singapore what a great experience the Satays are amazing we had the combination Satay platter for two Beef Chichen and Prawns 10 of each for $35 with satay sauce and Chilli sauce. An old man was was selling wet towels and you needed them by the time you finished eating the delicious Satays. Needed a couple of Tiger beers as the sauce are very spicy. Great night.

REVIEW_TITLE: A must to see & taste when your in SG!
REVIEW_BODY: The street is closed and all filled up with plastic furniture. Really nice to see. I guess you have like, 10 stands were they sell satay. Beef chicken and shrimp. You can choose a package deal or order just some loose pieces. Ladies walk around to bring you beer if you want. Really nice place to go to and a must when you visit Singapore.

We went there on a Sunday night. We were a bit concerned about what time Satay Street would actually open as some documentation said 9:00PM, some people told us 7:30....We went about 7:00 and it was cooking.

There is a large covered hawker center where you can get all type of foods, but the satays are outside so make sure you don't eat inside without seeing the outdoor action
.
When we entered the inside section, there were people trying to get you to sit at a particular table. Just keep walking and when you get to satays, they will help you.
We ate at the 7 and 8 stalls and the people were very helpful in getting a table and explaining the menu. The menu is all satay...combinations of chicken, beef/mutton, and prawns. They were all tasty + peanut sauce was good.

If you want additional non-satay items, you can get served at the outside tables +
drink-lady tigers are on the prowl to get you beverages.

It is easy to get to by taxi, grab or uber (uber is going to be gone in the near future, so download grab before you go --- it is works the same as uber and is easy to use.)

Have fun and enjoy a unique place.

I checked the reviews on here before we went to La Pau Sat: Hawker Food Stalls. We loved the relaxed chilled out atmosphere and varied choice of foods available. Outside especially in the street fun, total mix of families, couples, business people etc. You do get venders with cards follow you offering you a card with pictures to choose food off. But that can be helpful if you don‚Äôt know what Asian food to have, we didn‚Äôt find them pushy more helpful and polite. We really like No 7/8 Stall satay platter of food was lovely, the prawns delicious the meat not massive I agree but tasty. It cost 26 dollars we thought it was good value. It is based outside but you can sit anywhere there is a free table, you do need tissues and wipes. The beer jug best value at 20dollars. We went a few times.

We went here for dinner. Great to sit and just watch it all. They close a street Down at night and set up tables for everyone to eat at
We had a range of satay sticks.
There is also girls that come around offering orders for beer to so no need to get up

Walked around as the stalls were just setting up. We opted to eat in the covered mall area.
When we came out later Satay Street was taken over by lots of bench type tables, chairs and crowds of people all enjoying Satay.

The smell was lovely. We will try this next time .

This is exactly what we wanted when we started reading about Singapore hawker food culture. Set behind Lau Pa Sat, this closed off street is lined with hawker booths serving chicken, prawn and beef satay. We are from booth 7&8 and enjoyed it all. Be sure to have $1 for napkins. A true must do Singapore experience.

For me, Satay Street is a must see while in Singapore. It's an experience we won't soon forget! We arrived later in the evening (around 10/10:30pm) on a weekday and didn't find it to be too crowded at that time. The menu items start with sets of 20+ skewers, but you can easily order less. Our favorites were the beef & prawns from Satay 7/8.

Eat here after being interested by it after reading in our Lonely Planet. It is as described, 8 stalls of Satay sellers all jostling to sell you their satays. Its an experience and the satays taste amazing. If you can cope with the harrassment of the stall holders and the street sellers- Someone tried to sell us tissues, two women tried to sell us beer and another man asked us if we wanted pitta with our meals.... We had been sat down for all of 2 minutes. You have to be firm and know exactly what you want otherwise you may end up being pursuaded into something else.

We picked a busy stall quickly and i had 10 chicken satays (0.70c each) which was $7 SGD. you can get a mix of satays (lamb and prawn too) for about $25 dollars or any amount/ mix you want.
I went back here as i loved the atmosphere, and the satays are amazing!

Must if you like this kind of food!
We wandered over from our hotel before catching the gardens by the bay light show. We had about 30 satays for around 20 dollars. It's busy, smoky, delicious and fun!

Plenty of signage to say this stall had the best satay and had won awards.

We were in a bit of a rush so didn't really look around and trusted the TripAdvisor logo.

Had chicken, beef and prawn. The prawn was really good however the beef and chicken was dry and overcooked.

We will go back as there was a lot of atmosphere and I'm sure there are better options. Would probably try their satay again as this could have been a one off.

My wife and I went to satay street on our last trip to Singapore and it was a real high light. you can smell the satay smoke from about 2 streets away. The place was mobbed and there was guys touting or you to eat at there place, we just want with the flow and sat at the first place the satay was $0.70 per stick, it was suggested that we got a mixed plate.

The food was awesome and we ate a pile, the one thing that I would say is that I ate 20 sticks and my wife ate 10 (the record is 200 in 20min) this was more than enough but as we had not been specific on how much we wanted we were given a MASSIVE pile and had 28 left I would say 30-35 (10beef, 10 chicken and 10 pork) between 2 would be perfect and you can always get more!

Do not miss this place it is a gem!

We looked forward so much to experience Satay street dinner at stalls 7/8...but it turned out to be the worst experience we had on our trip!! The workers there hassle you so much!! Before you make a decision they sit you down on a dirty (taped up) table...menu up in your face!! The satay meat was very rubbery...we had to spit most of it out!! We ordered some fried rice with satay...but was served noodles instead and they insist we had to pay for their error!!

Nice street, very yummy smells everywhere. I guess you can find better satays but the quality was ok. When you arrive you can choose to see in different location (about 10 small houses) we were on the second one they were nice.
I recommend for the experience.

"Satay street", as it is nicknamed is located on the street next to the Telok Ayer Market and right next to the Sofitel Hotel. Easy to get to by MTR. Many street vendors sells satay there so you can't go wrong. The one we picked offered a package of satay for $29SD complete with beef, chicken, and good size prawns as shown on my photos. All very delicious for street food! You can buy all kinds of drinks from the vendors in the Telok Ayer Market as well as other kinds of food to add to your feast. Make sure you bring a lot of wet napkins because no one gives you anything to wipe with. It will be a messy dinner but well worth it.

REVIEW_TITLE: You've got to go - just an amazing experience at night
REVIEW_BODY: One of my friends told me about this place and mistakenly I went during the day initially and there was nothing much to see. When I went later that night - they whole street was alive with rows of tables and over a dozen stalls selling Satay or other Asian dishes. - The sound and the smells are amazing - staff are very friendly and the Satay are $6 or $7 for 10. Beer is also cheap.

The satay and beers were just what was required at the end of the day. The Tiger lady brought the beers to your table and the satay was fantastic. It was a highlight of the trip. Just don't go for the first hawker that approaches you.

Came here for dinner with my partner, we had been eating our way around singapore and we're excited for satay street. The food was ok, 5/10, very expensive for what it was (we got the smallest platter and a jug of beer and it set us back $46). Tourist trap, wouldn't recommend.

The only hawker centre we visited and we ate nowhere else during our whole week, this is the only one which had two price lists. One for locals and one (more expensive) for tourists which sums up who comes here. Don't bother coming, there are enough other centres with authentic local cooking and cheaper prices. By all means walk through to see how the street is taken over but eat elsewhere.

We were staying at the hotel across the street and could see this being setup from our bedroom window. We visited most nights of our stay for a quick satay snack and some beer. It's not overly expensive and we enjoyed trying them from each of the stalls. 5&6 were our favourites. Definitely worth trying a few as they were different. We didn't haggle on the satay as they were reasonable, 10 for $7, we did on the beer though as that was expensive.

Satay,Singapore...the Old Carparks (which this set up goes someway to replace) were oddly enough part of the charm of a balmy evening exploring the islands eateries.

This place is getting close to Gross! Cramped,rushed, commercial just ain't the same.

Lacks the "local" crafted homespun ambience, now it is so MASS produced and presented it's almost out of a packet!

Will go back because they sell Satay and it's accessible.
Visited Satay Street on the recommendation of friends and glad I did, fresh, tasty and cheap and just a short walk from the MRT. Definitely a must when in Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Satay at a very affordable price
REVIEW_BODY:
Located right outside of the Telok Ayer hawkers market, and also in between 3 subway stops, no wonder there are flooded tourists and locals here.
I came here alone and they have a few stalls, one lured me into his and offered 10x skewers at SG$7. There are a few more options such as 2-3 pax combo, group combos etc. Selections range from prawn, beef, chicken, and mittens.
Definitely a bit of a tourist trap and some stalls were a bit pushy (Singapore standards anyway) but had really good satay in a crazy environment. The bbq prawns were immense. Worth a visit.

REVIEW_TITLE: As name suggest ..street satay at night
REVIEW_BODY: This attraction starts in evening just outside food market on the street the street is closed off and satay stands.Alot of people wanting buy from their stalls.Order and grab a seat,minimum sticks of 10

I have seen the ‚ÄúSatay Street‚Äù at Lau Pa Sat described as a tourist trap, but as a traveller who visits Singapore a lot I would have to ask why is it full of locals if it is there to rip off tourists?

I was introduced to the food stalls here by a Singaporean colleague something like 18 years ago and have come very visit since. My favourite staff was Fatman‚Äôs, (No.1) sadly no longer there.

In essence, it is a row of around 12-14 (I never count) Satay stalls, each does slightly differently as they have different proprietors. You can also get food from inside La Pa Sat itself (a greater variety) or binge on Satay and a jug of beer (which I do, I have to admit). The stalls have to vie for business as they are competing with similar ‚Äúproducts‚Äù on all sides of them. It is not cheap (A jug of beer is about $17, or ¬£9.50 in post Brexit money) That‚Äôs good value by central Singapore standards. It is close to the financial district (right over the road from many Banking offices) so probably does price suffer just like the facilities around any Banking area do anywhere in the world and certainly Satay in Malaysia is cheaper, but not so handy if you‚Äôre sitting in the centre of a different country.

Overall it‚Äôs a nice experience to sit and eat here, with the locals and appreciative expats and tourists.

This is the proof that you dont Always need a star restaurant to get some delicious food. Even a simple satay can taste so nice and the atmosphere is making it even special. In Singapore you dont have to worry about the foodstalls, they are checked on regular base and get a label. The simple plastic furniture is good and never worry about the bill...its cheap. Just try and enjoy some different satays and a cold beer there.

If you can resist the smells of meat being cooked over hot coals then you don't suffer from the same weakness as me.

I stumbled across satay street on my first night and although I was planning to head elsewhere I had to stop off and sample the satay.

There are about 9 or 10 stalls selling satay and all seem to offer the same choice so just pick one and order. At the weekend the place is packed out with locals so it has a fabulous atmosphere and it's hard to beat eating fresh bbq'd meat on a plastic table in the warm

I'd suggest avoiding the tribe or lung satay. It's edible but not really to western tastes

The satay street starts at 7pm daily. The street is closed to traffic and you get to dine under the skyscrapers of Singapore. Great atmosphere as the place is super lively. Very enjoyable and memorable experience.

REVIEW_TITLE: Fantastic street food great atmosphere. We had prawn chicken and beef satay straight from the BBQ so tasty. Definitely a
REVIEW_BODY: This is definitely a must if in Singapore... prawn satay was the best, sat in the hustle and bustle of the city just fabulous. Such good value ...

There used to be a satay club where the esplanade stands today. But of course, with urban redevelopment, the entire satay club has been shifted here. Many satay stalls to choose from and most of them are good. Most probably because of the stiff competition.
Must walk through buzzing street when nightfall comes every day. Many stalls selling satay .. yummy chunks of meat on wooden skewers. Really Mouth-watering üòã

Place is worth seeing for its vibe and atmosphere however prices are way too high - we have paid close to 100 usd for satays and prawn - they were ok but not for that kind of money. Beer is 20 sgd per jug.

Great place for Satay in the centre of Singapore. Take MRT to Telok Ayer and a short walk to the Telok Ayer Market. Choose Satay 8 or 9 as the best choice. You can offer any combination and they car arrange beer, drinks, mee goring etc.

This is a great place for you to taste some nice satay in Singapore......so yummy and so juicy and so succulent. Try out different flavours ranging from chicken, beef and prawn. The aroma of the barbeque is just splendid and this place is constantly packed to the brim and it is very vibrant too. Not the cheapest but definitely one of the better places to enjoy the local delicacy.

Very busy place to eat. You will definitely be hassled by hawkers but thats all part of the fun. Large variety of food to choose from with rows of satay stalls. All very clean and the food we had was delicious!
They have the most delicious satay ever . their mutton satay were juicy . Their prawn and satay babat was awesome too . Its a must to eat Satay Power 6 in Lau Pa Sat

Satay street is probably the only street in Singapore that is shut completely at 7 PM to give way to hawkers who set up the most interesting satay stalls. Tried Prawn, chicken and mutton satay, barbecued to perfection and a sweet tinge, served with yummy peanut sauce, rice cake and salad.

I'm surprised this place has four stars. We went last night and were very disappointed. The minute we sat down, three different touts literally threw their menus on our table. We gave the menus back because we wanted to try specific stalls recommended in the reviews on this site, and a minute later, two of them came back and did it again. We ordered from four different stalls as we were curious about whether was a difference in quality. Turns out they were all uniformly bad. The satay sticks were tiny and flavourless, with the beef and mutton in particular being tough and chewy. The satay sauces from all four stalls were bland. The prawn satays were mealy. The food took ages to arrive and the Tiger Beer lady took so long, we thought she'd forgotten our order. Honestly, don't waste your time. There are much better satays to be had in Sinagpore. If you're going to come here, eat inside at the wonderful Lau Pa Sat hawker centre. I gave it one star because the atmosphere was okay.

Ordered a set from stalls 7/8, $41 for approx 40 tiny satay sticks is over the top. The flavor was nice but the sticks are so tiny it's definitely not value for money. Never mind, tried it once but won't be back. Positive: the atmosphere was good.

There are lots of satay vendors here, which starts selling after 7pm. I usually order the chicken satay, as I find the price of the grilled prawns rather overpriced. Most shops would bring you the satay to your table, but for the popular ones, you have to queue up and wait for the satay to be cooked for you.

Overall, it is a good experience to sit in the middle of the Central Business District of Singapore, having grilled meat and beer.

Eat a satay street. Open at night only, Satay Street is literally a street in the business district which gets closed off after hours. It is attached to Lau Pa Sat. There are numerous satay stalls on the street, so you can take your pick. I went with a local and her view is that they are all similar.

We ate a mixed platter of pork, chicken, beef and prawns. We also ordered some murtabak from another vendor. It was really delicious.

Bring your own tissues and wet wipes - this is messy.

REVIEW_TITLE: Definitely worth a visit, has a good vibe
REVIEW_BODY:
Enter the street and you get hit by dozens of people touting their food which is all part of the vibe.

We thought the satays were good though as many have commented a little up there in price but not out priced.

Next door is a Hawkers market with a large variety of different food.

I would make this one or your "to do's" while in Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: just nice for one time visit...
REVIEW_BODY: not totally tourist-friendly in terms of price...experience-wise is just nice...you can sit at satay street and order from the seafood stalls inside Lau Pa Sat.

Over priced with lousy satay. I spent 45 years in Singapore & I sure know this place don't serve satay as it is supposed to be. I m a local & the hawker dare serve me under cooked, non authentic satay that were way over priced. Visited this place once & I never return.
Visit any other place in Singapore & you will find yourself better tasting & cheaper satay.

On getting close I was immeadiately put off by the hawkers who try to grab you and take you to a table, then a menu of different meal options is thrust at you. The price of these "deals" is shockingly high, on wanting to just stroll the street to look and make our own decision it was just an awful experience of being constantly harrarsed by people trying to get you to sit in their area. There were only what appeared to be tourists here, I found it all very uncomfortable and we did not stay. Can not recommend this place at all.

A real hustling and bustling place - a number of vendors all trying to sell you their food. The vendor we chose served an excellent selection of satay all cooked and served fresh and piping hot and the beer was ice cold, what more could you ask for :)

It's really not about the food only. It is a regular street outside the Lau Pa Sat food Centre, that is closed to traffic after 7:00 pm. Like has been said, the satay is good, but better might be found elsewhere, the reason to go there is the atmosphere. It's like a street party. Stall 7 & 8 are frequently mentioned, we did not try anyone else so can't say definitively if they were the best, but they were good enough. I felt the chicken was a tad dry. It can be a little intimidating, to arrive at Satay street and immediately be accosted by the numerous stall representatives urging you to try their food. If you decide before hand which stall you want to patronize, it is helpful to wave the others off. What was interesting this time is that each stall seemed to have their little territory that you needed to sit in in order to order from them. We experienced one cautionary incident in which another stall representative selling roti and mee goreng brought the wrong order and attempted to charge a big price for it. And their noodles were judged as mediocre. People go there for the satay, the other food is a question mark.
This is a great place to meet friends or just enjoy eating satay steaks. Smoky, loud and fun, just the way it should be.

A nice spot for dinner...street shuts at 7pm and turns into the satay hub... Good variety of meats and good satay... Add some chilli from one of the other stalls inside to make it a bit better All things considered this is pretty darn good
Satay street is a must when visiting Singapore with amazing street food and beers. Great atmosphere and swift service

This is an essential part of any trip to Singapore in my opinion. It is a full-on multi-sensory experience full of noise, great smells and tastes, smoky air and pushy food vendors. I had a blast here with my friends eating an assortment of delicious beef, chicken and prawn satays and enjoying the high-spirited, bustling atmosphere. Loved it.
Super cheap - $1 per satay stick - and delicious. You sit on tables in the street at whichever vendor you like and just go for it (I sat at #8) . Will go back every time I'm in Singapore
A wonderful food experience and a must for anyone visiting Singapore, Stall 8 had the tastiest food, ask them to organise a veg fried rice and the naan bread to eat with your satay's

REVIEW_TITLE: Go to #07 or #08 in Satay Street
REVIEW_BODY: Why this number even though food is (almost) identical? Friendlyness of staff. Time from order to delivery. Always fresh draft beer!
A great experience. Make sure to barter on price. They'll start at $87 for skewers for 4 people. Great atmosphere and the food was delicious.
This is good hawker street food court.The food here is tasty and fresh.A good place to be in the evenings for drink and a meal with family and friends.
